Nitratireductor mangrovi is a species of bacteria that was isolated from mangrove sediments. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming, motile bacterium that belongs to the phylum Proteobacteria.

The cells of Nitratireductor mangrovi are typically rod-shaped and measure around 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.0-2.0 μm in length. The bacterium is capable of reducing nitrate to nitrite, which is an important process in the nitrogen cycle within mangrove ecosystems.

Nitratireductor mangrovi is considered a halotolerant species, meaning it can tolerate a wide range of salinity levels. This adaptation allows it to thrive in the brackish environments typical of mangrove habitats.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Nitratireductor mangrovi is closely related to other members of the genus Nitratireductor, which are known to play a role in the nitrogen transformations in various marine and estuarine environments.

The discovery and characterization of Nitratireductor mangrovi contribute to our understanding of the microbial diversity and the biogeochemical processes occurring in mangrove ecosystems, which are important coastal environments known for their ecological and economic significance.
